Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Non-planar heterostructures, particularly core-shell nanowires, exhibit a number of comparative advantages for optoelectronic applications with respect to conventional planar heterostructures. The analysis of dopant distribution and interface morphology is extremely challenging, however, limiting the understanding of fundamental growth processes that is needed to optimize the structure and properties. This project investigates the driving forces that control dopant and alloy element incorporation, diffusion, and segregation in non-planar heterostructures consisting of both Si-Ge and GaAs-AlGaAs core-shell nanowires. To this end, atom probe tomography, Hall effect measurements, Kelvin probe force microscopy, and micro-photoluminescence are used to relate doping levels, and fluctuations in composition, to electronic and optical properties. Numerical modeling of dopant diffusion during processing and electrical transport in device structures is based on and compared with quantitative, atomic scale composition information provided by the atom probe studies.

Non-technical Description: New materials, and conventional materials in new forms, can improve existing technologies and lead to the creation of new technologies. This project is developing a fundamental understanding of how known semiconductor materials, such as silicon and gallium arsenide, can be put together in new ways to better perform important functions, such as the efficient conversion of light to electrical energy and vice versa. The research activity is specifically focused on non-planar heterostructures, where "heterostructure" indicates the combination of two distinct materials and "non-planar" indicates that the junction between these materials has a complex three-dimensional form so as to better carry out key device functions. To analyze the shape of non-planar heterostructures and the distribution of tiny quantities of charge-controlling dopant atoms within them, a highly specialized microscope known as an atom probe tomographic is employed. The atom probe can look inside the very smallest devices that have ever been made and map out the distribution of all the elements that are present. The project incorporates an industrial perspective on the development of materials for new technologies by including a "co-op on campus" program, in which undergraduate research projects of relevance to the larger goals of the research are solicited from industrial partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project investigated the structure and properties of nanoscale semiconducting crystals with distinctive electronic and optical properties that may lead to new and better technologies for processing and communicating information. The primary experimental activity utilized a method known as atom probe tomography, which can reveal the position and identity of every atom in a nanoscale crystal. The project made significant contributions to advances in both methodology of materials characterization, thereby providing broader impact, and materials knowledge, thereby generating intellectual merit. The project’s advances in atom probe tomography methods provide guidance to scientists and engineers in academia and industry on how to better characterize their materials and devices, accelerating the development of new technologies. These advances are summarized in a book chapter, written by the lead grad student and principal investigator, that thoroughly describes the application of atom probe tomography to the analysis of semiconductor nanostructures. The book chapter will help novice users apply the method and will assist non-experts in critically assessing the research literature.  As a result of methodological advances, the project also provided important new knowledge of how one can tailor the growth conditions of nanoscale crystals to better control their structure and properties.

 

More specifically, the project advanced knowledge of how the shape of growing nanoscale crystals affects their composition. These semiconducting nanoscale crystals naturally have excellent electronic and optical properties, but more precise control of their composition on the nanometer scale is needed to provide a basis for engineering new electronic and photonic technologies. The project's investigations of nanoscale composition in three dimensions were the first of their kind on nanowire heterostructures- combinations of different semiconductor materials-enabling two important classes of results that support technology development. First, the research provided new understanding of how growth conditions can be tuned to more precisely control composition. Measurements were conducted on samples provided by a research group in Germany that is a world leader in these materials, providing relevance to academic and industrial researchers worldwide working on these materials. Second, the measurements and closely integrated modeling of properties revealed the sensitivity of novel devices to nanoscale composition fluctuations, providing clear targets for materials improvement and for engineering devices that will provide technological advantages.

 

The principal investigator's research group engaged two female Northwestern University PhD students in the research, as well as graduate students and faculty collaborators at the Technical University of Munich in Germany, and at Tel Aviv University in Israel. The lead PhD student on the project spent time with collaborators in Germany, and Northwestern hosted student visitors from Munich and from Tel Aviv University, contributing to the development of a globally capable workforce who are experts in best practices in materials characterization. The lead PhD student graduated at the end of the project and took a postdoctoral position at Argonne National Laboratory working on the materials for renewable energy applications, positioning herself to continue contributing to technological advances in the national interest.
